content: Hey everyone! :wave: Would we like to run our regular meeting in 15 minutes? Or in 1hr 15 minutes to adjust for daylight savings?
Either works for me
Either is ok with me too :) I sketched us an agenda here: https://hackmd.io/xYG2QqM6RZuOjA33Siwk1w
Shall we do in 1hr then and see if that times suits everyone better? The Error handling group has shifted theirs so it now collides with ours
Was there anything else anybody would like to add to the agenda?
Hey! :wave: Shall we get started?
@Caleb Zulawski Howâ€™s things going with https://github.com/rust-lang/stdsimd/pull/44? Were you still waiting on some feedback there? Or is it just the tests we need to get building again?
I think it's in good shape, I still need to do a bit of work on it
However I'm not sure if we actually agreed with doing masks that way
Ah have we not discussed it yet? I took the fact that weâ€™re bikeshedding the naming convention as a sign that itâ€™s in good shape :smiley:
We discussed it quite a bit before I actually wrote it up
But yeah I agree
Do you imagine itâ€™s likely to want to change much or should we try get it all merged and then leave it to a future pass over the API to make sure weâ€™re still happy with how it all fits together?
Iâ€™d be inclined to merge and do a bigger API review later, maybe before we try pull it in to std?
I don't think it'll change that much if we settle on that general design
With an opaque implementation-defined mask and the special masks
Is there anything else youâ€™d like a hand with?
Hmm nothing that I can think of off the top of my head
ah eff.
I think once we settle on some masks there's quite a bit that opens up
oh hi.
We agreed on experimenting with different mask implementations.
So would we like to sketch out an alternative then before merging #44?
Not even sure where that link goes...
Not that much? I think alternatives might make themselves more obvious when we have any practical work with it done.
I will try to give it a review rather than being continually clogged on vague gesture The World.

Ashley Mannix said:

Not even sure where that link goes...

2010, what a year it was
( I have been paying attention but not that closely. )
Would we like to spend any more time on masks now while weâ€™re here?
( which is itself also a good sign since I did glance at it and nothing like "OH NO THIS IS CLEARLY WRONG" jumped out at me. )
At Caleb's option?
Other things to maybe mention: aarch64 is now tier 1 soon, we still haven't solved the RISCV blocker.
I noticed some murmurs in the cranelift channel about building a new RISCV backend for it tho'.
aarch64 shouldn't cause any problems for us, and I have an intuition that whatever we do to improve cranelift compatibility may remove the RISCV blocker also, one way or another.
Ah interesting... I thought the RISCV blocker was LLVM specific?
It looked like it was, but I'm not sure we figured that out definitively
It is but it arrived the moment we pulled LLVM stuff directly into our API instead of through a rustc-abstracted API.
So this is why I called it an intuition/hunch rather than a soundly reasoned argument.
Ahh ok. Maybe we should try reach out in t-compiler specifically and see if they have any input?
Sure, we did raise the issue in rust-lang but didn't get any responses IIRC?
Yeh, it mightâ€™ve just flown under the radar a bit ðŸ™‚
Sounds sensible, yeah.

So weâ€™ve got a MCP going to pull those LLVM intrinsics out, like @Jubilee mentioned. Itâ€™s been updated with a little more detail after a first round of compiler input. Does it seem reasonable to you all? https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/381
Or do you envisage it working differently?

Alright. This looks slightly more complex than I would like, but it still looks good, and I get the hunch that this has driven in this direction because it is the most compatible with the current infra.
And also from my lack of imagination about how we could do it :smile:
/shrug
Mm, I think this is just hard to cram in there at the moment since anything more would require significantly more refactorings.
of like

the entire compiler.
so it's hard to apply Vision:tm: and not generate an even larger pile of work to do.
since like, our initial idea was "well what if MIR is changed?" which was uh Pretty Big Already and this looks more minimal than that.
It does live at the intersection of a bunch of different compiler pieces. In the meantime we can try introduce some of our missing simd_ intrinsics
and that alone is an improvement.
While I'm on the bandwagon we've also got a PR for allowing #[repr(simd)] on arrays: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/78863
I saw! :3
It's currently failing some codegen tests, which I'll try work through, but might need some help there :smile:

okay my own todo for the next week:
review two PRs / see if I can help you with that
and try to start poking to see if we can push the LLVM linkages out of our current API, behind the platform intrinsics, and if that will fix our RISCV problem.
...also finally get a proper calendar set up. :V
Speaking of, are we happy with this time now?
It's good for me, but we only got 3 so uhhh idk!
I suspect that will require more MetaDiscussion.
( I also suspect we have exhausted our set of thoughts to sync on. )
It's uhhh a pleasure to be here when I remember it~ :sweat_smile:
So I think Friday will be when I'll be able to take a proper look at those codegen tests :smile: I have a big block of time in front of my desktop to work on stuff
Oh @Jubilee was there anything in packed_simd you'd like some more support with?
Hm. I will find out if there is and get back to you on that.
Alrighty, thanks for coming everyone! It's looking like we're getting ever closer to really shipping a complete portable SIMD API on stable Rust! :tada:
(deleted)
